reviews.review_msg: Grading is 20% per quiz, 40% final (also worst quiz dropped if u do better on final). If you do the lectures and exercises, the quizzes are very straightforward. Same concept for the final, Brad's exams are very fair. Super chill guy.
He is the best professor in statistics. If you can take a course with him, you won't regret it.

Good prof. Helpful through email & always asks class if they have questions. Class is organized well & teaching is pretty good. Didn't use Monday class (nice) & got vids instead. Sometimes went thru topics fast in the first few chapters. Quizzes r open book, long, &time crunched so study. Final was 3x as long but fair. Guided us in R. Useful class!

Professor Mcneney is probably one of the "better" professors for stat. He does talk really fast during lectures but he does try to reexplain concepts more clearly when asked to. He does often make mistakes for quiz questions so he would either omit it or change some grading.
Brad is a really good prof,  he made the things easy to understand, and clear lecture note .  the assignments and practices are very helpful to the exam. But speaks too fast.
Don't  understand what he is talking in class. He speaks so fast. Reading textbook is more helpful. Terrible handwriting. Midterm 1 is easy, midterm 2 is hard.
Brad is such a nice prof! He truly cares about his students and listens to their opinions. Exams are easy and the same as his practice questions! He also tells you what questions will be on the exam!

Very helpful if you go to his office hours. TA's are pretty much useless so his notes is really your backbone + his office hours. Hate the textbook but if you put the time into reading it, it's not TOO bad. HW was similar to the test so make sure you understand the HW!!

From the first moments of this class it was loaded with jargon and very few plain language explainations or examples. However the assignments wern't bad and the exams were really easy if you did the practice exams. The text book is awful (and $200 with suspiciously few used copys around for a book published in the 80's). All in all an okay class.

This teacher definitely knew his stuff, BUT didn't provide any examples in his notes or lectures that will allow you to understand homework and exam questions. The textbook this semester was awful. But practice exams are quite similar to real ones. How I managed to get an A I don't know.
He doesn't give examples of the material he is presenting, very hard to relate to a practical sense of learning.

Assignments are easy. TAs are helpful. But the final are all multiple choice questions, with 8 choices for each question. Some choices are ambiguous and the questions are totally different from the assignment and practice exams. Taking his distance course should consider twice before make the decision, because all you can do is read the textbook.

Never saw the Professor lol. The class had 3 assignments, each worth 10%, and the final was 70%. Assignments were easy, they were all in R and straight out of the textbook. Cheat sheet was allowed for the final and the questions were mostly from the textbook. So make sure to practice ALL the questions , gotta know a bit about simple R code too.
worst instructor ever.
lecture note are unorganized, not easy for searching

Tests, assignments are fair and clear on grading criteria. He is super prompt in replying emails, approachable and nice. Practical questions/assignments (using R) from the beginning to the end of the course. Super helpful

Professor Davis changed my feeling about stats at SFU. After his class I feel very confident in my ability to use the basics of R especially in regression. Tests are very similar to the extensive practice materials. He was always willing to answer any questions in class or in the stats workshop. A great class and great prof!

Clear notes provided, and he even scans what he doesn't have time to cover (sample questions/sample exams) for our study. Approachable and patient. Course is not hard, average is high with easy exams (before which you have sample exams which is very similar) and easy assignments (time-consuming though). Like his teaching and marking.

This prof is the worst professor at SFU. She is very disorganized and not helpful. Students sent her emails asking for help and she would say she was busy. She was not approachable. You basically have to teach yourself this course because she cant teach anything. If you have never taken stats dont take it with her because she is never helpful.

AVOID! The worst prof I've ever had. Very disorganized, no clear deadlines/grading criteria. Asks Qs that she never taught. No accommodating at all and things that she's the only one struggling with switch to online learning. THE WORST! P.S. She posts assgs/lectures randomly and gives very little time to complete those.

Prof Loughin is a very organized and detail-oriented Professor. She explains concepts very clearly and is always open to hearing her students' feedback and questions in and outside of her lecture time. She introduces R programming well and gives us a lot of practice homework to ensure that we have a solid knowledge of the programming language.

Theres a lot of assignments, but she is actually quite lenient on deadline. She answers emails promptly and her and TAs give lots of good feedback. She follows the book quite closely so its not a big deal if you miss a lecture. I would go to lecture if you arent great at reading R input though.

Marie Loughin is a great professor! I don't know where these negative reviews are coming from. I work hard as a student & actually show up to class (more than 50% of the class never showed up for lectures). If you study her lecture notes and understand concepts, you can easily get an A. Please do not listen to these comments below lol.

lectures can be boring. Lectures follow text but provide new examples. midterms and final allow CHEAT SHEETS! know interpretation for parameters, confidence/prediction intervals, F-tests and T-test. Overall fair midterms and final and marking is fair. Workshop for really helpful. 5-6 homework assignments and a lot of time given for them. Manageable

The prof was awesome! He is very kind and helpful. Lectures were interesting, and his exam was fair.  The class average was pretty high. An excellent prof with great teaching skills and looks to match =)
Great Prof!! clear notes, always willing to help outside of class. really wants every student to succeed! understands how to teach!
Very fair, well organized, and kept things interesting. He was funny and I actually looked forward to coming to class ... and not just because he was so cute! :)
Was very fair and clear for all the material in the course. Especially for a Stats course, awesome teacher.
Statistics isn't super interesting, in my opinion, but he's hot enough to make it worthwhile to go to class.
He is so cute!! And awesome (so far) at teaching.

Avoid this prof if you can. He's ancient and doesn't know the modern way to teach. His notes are all on overheads and they are illegible. He doesn't provide any help to those who ask for it and he is not sympathetic to the needs of his students. It's almost impossible to pass his course unless you get extra help. Worst prof I've ever had.
Good luck. Get yourself a tutor or be prepared to teach everything to yourself. He cannot explain anything clearly. Avoid him at all costs and take this with a prof who is reputable for teaching 302.

By far one of the WORST PROFESSORS I have had. He can't teach worth #@!%. He is just all over the place. He has no teaching script and just wings it Starts the semeste WITHOUT a quick review. just jumps into hard material and 90percent of the class is lost. AVOID THIS PROF!However, he is a nice guy, likes to talk about useless stuff time to time.

Very nice, responsible and helpful prof.  exams are very straight forward.  If you do all his online reading and know what is going on during lecture, its not hard to get an A.  Assignments give you very good practice for midterm.

Very clear but doesn't have the best writing.  Very ugly in fact, sometimes hard to read.  The class itself was very easy if you did all the hwk.  Didn't even open the textbook so just use the notes he gives you and online.

Best stats prof by far, in his lectures he breaks down concepts into very simple concepts for students to understand. Sometimes he will even add in if itll be tested on the exam. Although the final was worth 50% it's an online course so I guess it's understandable. Just wish he provided more practice content but overall highly recommend
Best statistics professor!!!
best prof at sfu , made concepts really easy to understand. He replies to emails super quick, even at 12am. The tests are fair and mainly come out of the textbook

Paying tuition and self-learn the whole course. No slides for the course and the lecture video barely talks about the content from the textbook. Self-study the whole textbook and make sure you do well in assignments as they count for 40%. The final Exam with 60% is stressing people out and no one finished the final exam within the time limit
You have to be able to self-study to do well in this course. His videos tell you what to focus on in the textbook.

No Powerpoints, practice exercises or resources. Textbook contains very little Rstudio codes. In the syllabus, he says you will have to teach yourself codes through "googling." TA is very slow in answering emails and providing feedback. Good luck!

The exam of this class had nothing to do with what was in the textbook and was designed to fail you. I have a 4.0+ GPA, self-taught myself the entire textbook, got good marks on assignments, and only got a B.

If you are looking to maintain a high GPA or improve your GPA, NEVER take a class with Tim. Even if you put the work in you'll get a mediocre grade since the final exam has nothing to do with the rest of the course and is completely luck-based. It honestly amazes me that this man is allowed to teach.

Tim is the worst prof I've had so far. The final exam was worth 60% and covered material that was never taught. This prof is unbelievably lazy; he wasted our time with telling silly stories during lecture, and even said he wouldn't be responding to any emails for the semester. Any class with this prof is a GPA destroyer.

Very disengaged with the class. Most learning done through assigned textbook readings. Assignments and especially the exam were disconnected from the material covered. Some of the questions on the exam made me doubt he knew what content he was assigning to be covered. Final felt very luck based with 20 mc questions being worth 60% of the grade.

First things first: The final exam is absolutely ridiculous. Even after spending days upon days studying the course material and doing the sample finals that he gave, the final was so detached from the rest of the course and was based off of luck, not knowledge. Save your money and GPA, do not take a course with Tim. Worst experience of my life.

Everyone fell asleep in his class~ he explained things too clearly~ But if you pay attention in class... you don't have to touch the boring textbook... except when you write stuff inside before you bring the textbook to his open book exam~~
Biased prof with sketchy understanding.

For 305: would recommend any other prof other than her for this class. No cheat sheets allowed unlike every other stats class, given 3 formulas to help for the entire course. Class average is borderline 50%. And if you don't pass the final, you fail the course. Wish I dropped out before the deadline and taken a different prof.

This is for stat 305 but it was not an option. Horrible. No formula sheet during exams, no cheat sheet, expected to memorize EVERYTHING. exam is fully written no MC. got mad at us when the midterms average was extremely low even though she is obviously the reason its so low. expecting us to memorize equations on top of definitions is horrible
Awful, Awful. Avoid Avoid

Rachel is one of the best teachers I have seen so far. She exactly knows how to explain a new concept so that students do not get confused. She was always quickly available to answer student questions. we had an exam or an assignment almost every two weeks throughout the term, which was really helpful for learning the course materials. Perfect!!

STAT302 Final average grade is C+, midterm average is around 50% to 60%,I took six upper courses in these two semesters and got five A levels, but 302 was a B.If you want a high GPA, Rachel is definitely not your choice.

Amazing professor. Super accessible outside class; the discussion forms are extremely helpful and she replies within the day. Does a great job re-explaining concepts if they're unclear. Bad ratings are likely from those that don't put in the effort to understand the material. I would recommend a very basic knowledge of R before taking this course.
Speechless course.
A solid professor. The lectures give you the tools you need to complete the assignments and for the tests.

I really liked Rachel. Very helpful and caring, lectures were pretty clear even though the class was quite challenging. Once you finish viewing all the lecture videos, the assignments and the exams are very doable!

Prof was very nice, assignments were straightforward and she was always willing to answer any questions. Final was straightforward as well. Overall I enjoyed this class and would take another class with her
I know there are comments about her accent, but it's still understandable. She scaled the finals by a lot too. She genuinely wants her students to get good grades, will take a course with her again.

Professor Lin always has the way of making complicated concepts easy to understand. Her classes are well-structured and clearly organized. The exam material is always reasonable, and as long as you carefully complete her practice questions, achieving a high grade is attainable. Overall, she is an excellent and responsible professor.

Becky's teaching is an organizational mess. Inconsistent, unexplained notation and concepts are weirdly generalized, if at all.
 
I think she tries to simplify harder content, which is great, but doesn't do so effectively. The content is easier compared to most, but it could be so much better if she focused on WHY things happen, not just results.
